record.text:
Claudeはわりかし自分を大きく見せるための嘘は目立たないというか、実直気味な回答な印象。
というか大手のAIが、初手から自分を凄く見せるために体裁だけは無茶苦茶立派で尤もらしい大きな嘘を仕掛けてくるのが異常なだけだが。

「妻が夫の姓を名乗るという慣習は、ローマ・オランダ法に存在しており、この形で南アフリカの慣習法に導入された」ということについて調べるのにAI頼ったら、まずcopilotがこの文献にこう書いてあるとか大嘘ついて、copilotの大嘘を検証するのにgeminiとchatgptにききながら進めたら、geminiも大嘘つきはじめて、裏取りしまくらなければならず、自分で調べるより無駄な労力と時間がかかった。
copilotとか、ヨーロッパから喜望峰到達より前に死んでる人がローマ・オランダ法の南アフリカへの移入過程について書いているとか言い出したんだが。マジネトウヨ相手にするのと同じような感じ。

record.text:
🖋️ “Stop Trump’s assault on democracy! Pass the Protecting Our Democracy Act NOW!” hit 500 signers!

💬 Text SIGN POSXHQ to 50409

external.description:
Text SIGN POSXHQ to 50409 — As the Trump administration continues its systematic assault on democratic institutions, constitutional checks and balances, and the rights and freedoms of every American, it has never been more urgent for Congress to debate and pass legislation to guard against executive overreach, including the Protecting Our Democracy Act (PODA).

The second Trump administration has demonstrated unprecedented contempt for the guardrails and norms that protect our democracy – from weaponizing federal law enforcement against political opponents and ordinary Americans to undermining judicial independence, from abusing emergency powers to evading congressional oversight, from dismantling federal agencies to siphoning billions of dollars to Trump family businesses. President Trump’s actions directly threaten our system of government and the freedoms of speech, association, and equal justice that every American depends on. PODA includes essential reforms to restore accountability and prevent future abuses of executive power.

Americans deserve a government bound by law, not presidential vendettas, as well as legal protections that secure liberty and justice beyond the reach of any single administration.

PODA’s essential reforms – which were offered during both Republican and Democratic administrations alike – would rebuild the constitutional safeguards our democracy requires: curbing pardon power abuses, ensuring no president is above the law, enforcing constitutional emoluments provisions, ensuring whistleblowers are protected, strengthening congressional oversight, protecting the power of the purse, limiting presidential national emergencies, preserving law enforcement independence from political manipulation, and more. By protecting these guardrails, PODA also protects the rights and freedoms of every American.

Without these legislative measures that build upon the Nixon-era anti-corruption reforms, we face the continued erosion of democratic norms, the concentration of unchecked power in the executive branch at the expense of Congress, and the loss of fundamental rights that have defined our nation for generations. That is precisely the authoritarian drift our constitutional system was designed to prevent.

This is not about partisan politics: it is about constitutional governance and the protection of our basic freedoms. Congress has the constitutional authority and moral obligation to act. Every official who has taken an oath to uphold the Constitution must recognize the gravity of this moment. Inaction enables autocracy.

I urge the Senate to pass the Protecting Our Democracy Act immediately. Thanks.
external.title: Stop Trump’s assault on democracy! Pass the Protecting Our Democracy Act NOW!

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "Street Racing in the Philippines - The Local Scene, Culture, and Community" on @Spreaker #autos #carnews #carpodcast #cars #culture #in #philippines #racing #street #the

external.description: This episode explores the dynamic and often controversial world of street racing in the Philippines, examining its historical roots and evolution from post-WWII American influence to its current form. It describes street racing as a clandestine activity driven by adrenaline, mechanical skill, and a strong sense of community, contrasting it with sanctioned motorsports due to its accessibility and lack of formal structure. The piece also addresses the dangers and legal challenges faced by participants, while highlighting the cultural significance of car modification and the camaraderie within the racing community. Ultimately, the episode reflects on the future of this subculture, considering the potential for government support to transition enthusiasts from illegal street racing to safer, sanctioned events.
external.title: Street Racing in the Philippines - The Local Scene, Culture, and Community

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "The Origins of Street Racing - From Japan’s Touge Roads to Hollywood" on @Spreaker #auto #carnews #carpodcast #cars #of #origins #racing #street

external.description: The epsiode offers an extensive overview of street racing, tracing its origins and evolution as a global cultural phenomenon. It begins by exploring the birth of touge racing in post-World War II Japan, highlighting the hashiriya subculture and the significant influence of manga and anime like Initial D. The explanation then shifts to the spread of street racing to the West, detailing the emergence of American drag racing and the subsequent integration of Japanese Domestic Market (JDM) car culture. Finally, the episode examines how Hollywood, particularly The Fast and the Furious franchise, propelled street racing into the mainstream, influencing global car culture while also prompting the rise of legal alternatives and professional motorsports like drifting.
external.title: The Origins of Street Racing - From Japan’s Touge Roads to Hollywood

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "10 Unforgettable Cars from Rust Valley Restorers" on @Spreaker #carnews #carpodcast #cars #restorers #rust #valley

external.description: The episode offers an overview of Rust Valley Restorers, a Canadian documentary series that chronicles Mike Hall and his team at Rust Bros Restorations as they revitalize classic cars in Tappen, British Columbia. It highlights ten iconic transformations featured on the show, ranging from a 1968 Chevy Camaro Convertible, noted for being the most expensive sale and a donation to Habitat for Humanity, to a 1969 AMC AMX discovered in Hall's vast collection. The show emphasizes the team's technical skill, creativity, and passion for preserving automotive history, often incorporating emotional client stories and balancing restoration challenges with budget constraints. Each vehicle, whether a muscle car or a vintage truck, illustrates the show's core theme of turning rusty relics into roadworthy treasures and the enduring appeal of classic automobiles.
external.title: 10 Unforgettable Cars from Rust Valley Restorers

저작권이나 개개인의 권리침해 이런 당연한 문제를 체쳐두고서라도, 그냥 평범하게 노래듣고 싶은 사람들의 영역에 AI곡이나 플리가 멋대로 껴드는 경험은 진짜 최악이에요. 따로 분류해서 원하는 사람만 듣게 하지 좀......

Tech is tech. We forget that wheels, fountains, cars, were tech once, something new and exciting. Our brains making something new.

Is tech our new religion?

external.description: Political violence in the United States is a complex and multifaceted issue, encompassing acts ranging from terrorism and assassinations to assaults, threats, and property damage motivated by ideological or partisan goals. It is important to note that the vast majority of Americans, across party lines, reject such violence—surveys consistently show that 80-90% view it as never justified, and incidents remain rare relative to overall crime rates (e.g., politically motivated murders account for less than 0.1% of total homicides since 2020). However, data from multiple independent sources, including academic studies, government reports, and nonprofit trackers like the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED), and the Global Terrorism Database (GTD), indicate that violence linked to right-wing ideologies has been more prevalent and lethal in recent decades compared to left-wing ideologies.  To address the question directly: Based on available empirical evidence, the Republican Party (or more precisely, individuals and groups associated with right-wing extremism, such as white supremacists, anti-government militias, and anti-abortion radicals) is linked to more incidents of political violence than the Democratic Party (or left-wing groups like Antifa or environmental/animal rights extremists). This conclusion holds across metrics like fatalities, attacks on people, and overall incidents since the 1990s, though left-wing violence—often focused on property damage during protests—has risen modestly in recent years. Islamist extremism, unrelated to either major party, accounts for a significant share of historical fatalities (primarily due to 9/11) but has declined sharply post-2001.  Key Data and Trends Data collection on political violence is challenging due to varying definitions (e.g., some sources focus on terrorism, others on broader assaults or threats), but patterns emerge from rigorous, nonpartisan analyses. Here's a summary of findings from major sources:  | Source | Time Period | Key Findings on Right-Wing vs. Left-Wing Violence | |--------|-------------|--------------------------------------------------| | Global Terrorism Database (GTD) / Profiles of Individual Radicalization in the U.S. (PIRUS) (University of Maryland, START Consortium) | 1970–2020 (U.S. focus) | Right-wing extremists committed 75% of ideologically motivated homicides (e.g., 227 incidents, 520+ deaths); left-wing: 19% (42 incidents, 78 deaths). Right-wing attacks are more likely to target people and result in fatalities. Islamist: ~6%. Left-wing acts are less violent overall (probability of violence: 0.33 for left vs. 0.61 for right). | | CSIS Terrorism Database | 1994–2020 | Of 893 terrorist incidents/plots, 57% right-wing (e.g., white supremacy, anti-government); 25% left-wing (e.g., anarchism, anti-capitalism); 15% religious (mostly Islamist); 3% ethnonationalist. Right-wing incidents rose sharply post-2016, outpacing all others. | | Reuters Investigation | 2021–2023 | Of 213 political violence incidents, most deadly attacks (13 of 14 fatal ones, 34 deaths) were by right-wing perpetrators (e.g., Trump supporter shooting a neighbor over politics). Left-wing: 1 fatal attack. Overall, ~2/3 of incidents were assaults/clashes; right-wing more often targets people. | | Cato Institute Analysis (post-9/11 focus) | 2001–2025 | Excluding 9/11 (2,977 deaths, Islamist), right-wing: 63% of 391 murders; left-wing: 10% (65 murders); Islamist: 21% of recent murders (81 total since 2020). Right-wing dominates non-fatal incidents too. | | ACLED / Journal of Democracy | 2016–2021 | Right-wing violence surged (e.g., Jan. 6 Capitol riot: 5 deaths, 140+ injured officers); left-wing protests (e.g., BLM) saw more property damage but fewer fatalities. Police used greater force at left-wing events, but right-wing incidents were more lethal. | | Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI) | 2024 Survey | 24% of Republicans (vs. 10% Democrats) support violence if the 2024 election is "compromised"; 27% of Trump-favoring Republicans endorse it to "save the country." Overall, 1 in 6 Americans back violence, but higher among Republicans. | | University of California, Davis Centers for Violence Prevention | 2025 Surveys | Republicans (esp. MAGA subset) more likely to endorse violence for political goals (58% of MAGA Republicans vs. 25% non-Republicans). MAGA Republicans 2-3x more likely to justify force for objectives like "stopping illegal immigration" or "returning Trump to power." |  Fatalities and Lethality: Right-wing extremists have caused the most deaths in the U.S. since 1990 (e.g., Oklahoma City bombing: 168 deaths, 1995; El Paso shooting: 23 deaths, 2019; Buffalo supermarket: 10 deaths, 2022). Left-wing fatalities are lower and often tied to older events (e.g., Weather Underground bombings in the 1970s). Recent examples include the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack (right-wing, 5 deaths) and the 2017 congressional baseball shooting (left-wing, 0 deaths but multiple injuries). Incidents and Targets: Right-wing violence more often involves firearms and targets individuals (e.g., politicians, minorities); left-wing more commonly involves vandalism or clashes at protests (e.g., 2020 Portland unrest). From 2021–2025, Reuters tracked ~200 incidents post-Jan. 6, with right-wing actors in the majority of lethal cases. Support and Attitudes: Polls (e.g., YouGov, PRRI) show Republicans more concerned about left-wing violence (69% blame left), while Democrats worry more about right-wing (60% blame right). However, objective data shows higher endorsement of violence among Republicans (e.g., 18% of Republicans vs. 8% Democrats say violence is sometimes justified). Younger liberals are slightly more likely to say violence can be "sometimes justified" in polls, but actual incidents don't reflect this. Recent Context (2024–2025): Incidents include the assassination of Charlie Kirk (motive unclear, but speculated left-leaning); shooting of Minnesota Rep. Melissa Hortman (Democrat, right-wing suspect); arson at Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's (Democrat) residence; and attacks on Tesla sites (anti-Musk, possibly left-leaning). Through mid-2025, ~150 politically motivated attacks occurred, per University of Maryland data, with right-wing still predominant.  Drivers and Broader Context Political violence isn't inherent to any party but is fueled by polarization, disinformation, economic anxiety, and inflammatory rhetoric from leaders on both sides. Right-wing surges correlate with events like the 2016 election and election denialism (e.g., "stolen election" narratives). Left-wing spikes tie to social justice protests (e.g., 2020). Social media amplifies threats, and conspiracy theories (e.g., QAnon, replacement theory) predict violence per studies in Terrorism and Political Violence. Experts like those at Brookings and Carnegie note that while left-wing violence is rising (e.g., Antifa clashes), it remains less lethal and organized than right-wing militias.  Both parties' leaders have condemned recent violence (e.g., Biden and Trump after Kirk's death), but blame-shifting (e.g., Trump calling it "radical left" rhetoric) can escalate tensions. Historians compare today to the 1960s–1970s (e.g., assassinations of JFK, MLK), but note current risks are higher due to partisanship and guns (U.S. has more firearms than people).  Recommendations from Experts To reduce violence: De-escalate Rhetoric: Leaders should avoid dehumanizing opponents (e.g., "enemies of the people"). Strengthen Institutions: Ensure election integrity and responsive governance to build trust. Counter Extremism: Cross-party efforts for threat assessment, mental health support, and social media regulation. Community Focus: Local programs to address grievances without violence.  In summary, while violence threatens democracy from all angles, evidence points to right-wing sources as responsible for more in the U.S. today. Addressing it requires nonpartisan action to restore norms of peaceful discourse.

It is important to note that the vast majority of Americans, across party lines, reject such violence—surveys consistently show that 80-90% view it as never justified, and incidents remain rare relative to overall crime rates (e.g., politically motivated murders account for less than 0.1% of total homicides since 2020). However, data from multiple independent sources, including academic studies, government reports, and nonprofit trackers like the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED), and the Global Terrorism Database (GTD), indicate that violence linked to right-wing ideologies has been more prevalent and lethal in recent decades compared to left-wing ideologies.  To address the question directly: Based on available empirical evidence, the Republican Party (or more precisely, individuals and groups associated with right-wing extremism, such as white supremacists, anti-government militias, and anti-abortion radicals) is linked to more incidents of political violence than the Democratic Party (or left-wing groups like Antifa or environmental/animal rights extremists). This conclusion holds across metrics like fatalities, attacks on people, and overall incidents since the 1990s, though left-wing violence—often focused on property damage during protests—has risen modestly in recent years. Islamist extremism, unrelated to either major party, accounts for a significant share of historical fatalities (primarily due to 9/11) but has declined sharply post-2001.  Key Data and Trends Data collection on political violence is challenging due to varying definitions (e.g., some sources focus on terrorism, others on broader assaults or threats), but patterns emerge from rigorous, nonpartisan analyses. Here's a summary of findings from major sources:  | Source | Time Period | Key Findings on Right-Wing vs. Left-Wing Violence | |--------|-------------|--------------------------------------------------| | Global Terrorism Database (GTD) / Profiles of Individual Radicalization in the U.S. (PIRUS) (University of Maryland, START Consortium) | 1970–2020 (U.S. focus) | Right-wing extremists committed 75% of ideologically motivated homicides (e.g., 227 incidents, 520+ deaths); left-wing: 19% (42 incidents, 78 deaths). Right-wing attacks are more likely to target people and result in fatalities. Islamist: ~6%. Left-wing acts are less violent overall (probability of violence: 0.33 for left vs. 0.61 for right). | | CSIS Terrorism Database | 1994–2020 | Of 893 terrorist incidents/plots, 57% right-wing (e.g., white supremacy, anti-government); 25% left-wing (e.g., anarchism, anti-capitalism); 15% religious (mostly Islamist); 3% ethnonationalist. Right-wing incidents rose sharply post-2016, outpacing all others. | | Reuters Investigation | 2021–2023 | Of 213 political violence incidents, most deadly attacks (13 of 14 fatal ones, 34 deaths) were by right-wing perpetrators (e.g., Trump supporter shooting a neighbor over politics). Left-wing: 1 fatal attack. Overall, ~2/3 of incidents were assaults/clashes; right-wing more often targets people. | | Cato Institute Analysis (post-9/11 focus) | 2001–2025 | Excluding 9/11 (2,977 deaths, Islamist), right-wing: 63% of 391 murders; left-wing: 10% (65 murders); Islamist: 21% of recent murders (81 total since 2020). Right-wing dominates non-fatal incidents too. | | ACLED / Journal of Democracy | 2016–2021 | Right-wing violence surged (e.g., Jan. 6 Capitol riot: 5 deaths, 140+ injured officers); left-wing protests (e.g., BLM) saw more property damage but fewer fatalities. Police used greater force at left-wing events, but right-wing incidents were more lethal. | | Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI) | 2024 Survey | 24% of Republicans (vs. 10% Democrats) support violence if the 2024 election is "compromised"; 27% of Trump-favoring Republicans endorse it to "save the country." Overall, 1 in 6 Americans back violence, but higher among Republicans. | | University of California, Davis Centers for Violence Prevention | 2025 Surveys | Republicans (esp. MAGA subset) more likely to endorse violence for political goals (58% of MAGA Republicans vs. 25% non-Republicans). MAGA Republicans 2-3x more likely to justify force for objectives like "stopping illegal immigration" or "returning Trump to power." |  Fatalities and Lethality: Right-wing extremists have caused the most deaths in the U.S. since 1990 (e.g., Oklahoma City bombing: 168 deaths, 1995; El Paso shooting: 23 deaths, 2019; Buffalo supermarket: 10 deaths, 2022). Left-wing fatalities are lower and often tied to older events (e.g., Weather Underground bombings in the 1970s). Recent examples include the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack (right-wing, 5 deaths) and the 2017 congressional baseball shooting (left-wing, 0 deaths but multiple injuries). Incidents and Targets: Right-wing violence more often involves firearms and targets individuals (e.g., politicians, minorities); left-wing more commonly involves vandalism or clashes at protests (e.g., 2020 Portland unrest). From 2021–2025, Reuters tracked ~200 incidents post-Jan. 6, with right-wing actors in the majority of lethal cases. Support and Attitudes: Polls (e.g., YouGov, PRRI) show Republicans more concerned about left-wing violence (69% blame left), while Democrats worry more about right-wing (60% blame right). However, objective data shows higher endorsement of violence among Republicans (e.g., 18% of Republicans vs. 8% Democrats say violence is sometimes justified). Younger liberals are slightly more likely to say violence can be "sometimes justified" in polls, but actual incidents don't reflect this. Recent Context (2024–2025): Incidents include the assassination of Charlie Kirk (motive unclear, but speculated left-leaning); shooting of Minnesota Rep. Melissa Hortman (Democrat, right-wing suspect); arson at Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's (Democrat) residence; and attacks on Tesla sites (anti-Musk, possibly left-leaning). Through mid-2025, ~150 politically motivated attacks occurred, per University of Maryland data, with right-wing still predominant.  Drivers and Broader Context Political violence isn't inherent to any party but is fueled by polarization, disinformation, economic anxiety, and inflammatory rhetoric from leaders on both sides. Right-wing surges correlate with events like the 2016 election and election denialism (e.g., "stolen election" narratives). Left-wing spikes tie to social justice protests (e.g., 2020). Social media amplifies threats, and conspiracy theories (e.g., QAnon, replacement theory) predict violence per studies in Terrorism and Political Violence. Experts like those at Brookings and Carnegie note that while left-wing violence is rising (e.g., Antifa clashes), it remains less lethal and organized than right-wing militias.  Both parties' leaders have condemned recent violence (e.g., Biden and Trump after Kirk's death), but blame-shifting (e.g., Trump calling it "radical left" rhetoric) can escalate tensions. Historians compare today to the 1960s–1970s (e.g., assassinations of JFK, MLK), but note current risks are higher due to partisanship and guns (U.S. has more firearms than people).  Recommendations from Experts To reduce violence: De-escalate Rhetoric: Leaders should avoid dehumanizing opponents (e.g., "enemies of the people"). Strengthen Institutions: Ensure election integrity and responsive governance to build trust. Counter Extremism: Cross-party efforts for threat assessment, mental health support, and social media regulation. Community Focus: Local programs to address grievances without violence.  In summary, while violence threatens democracy from all angles, evidence points to right-wing sources as responsible for more in the U.S. today. Addressing it requires nonpartisan action to restore norms of peaceful discourse.
